Whatever happened to truth in advertising? If Sushi Fantastic is any indication, it's gone the way of the dinosaur. I wish this was something we could resurrect (both truth in advertising and dinosaurs, I'd love to mount a T-Rex with cannons like in Dino Riders.)

Sushi Fantastic is by no means a bad restaurant, but the sushi is the worst thing on the menu. The rolls are so-so, and the nigiri isn't fresh. Freshness is the basis of good sushi. I'm not expecting cuts straight out of the Tsukiji Fish market or anything but it shouldn't seem like they've been laying around for a while either. If you want good sushi, there are plenty of other places to go in the city.

The soba was a sad disappointment. Just because it' is a noodle does not mean it is served the same way as ramen. Serving the soba in a ramen broth base is akin to travesty. It's an entirely different soup type altogether. TO be fair though, I've yet to find anywhere in the States that can make decent soba, which is a shame because it's not very difficult. What I would give to be able to get a box of noodles with dipping soba soup/sauce on the side again.

Misgivings aside, there are some things done very well here. The katsudon (pork cutlet) and tempura are very good. Well cooked and crisp while not being dry, the way it should be. The udon is also pretty good too, and I usually don't like udon (I heard good things so I had to try it, and I'm glad I did.) The service also deserves mention, as they're generally very fast, friendly and clean. Like some of my favorite women.

Food is three stars. Service four. Name two.

So word to the wise, if you go to Sushi Fantastic, don't go for the sushi. Get a bento box, try a bowl of Udon or some donburi. There's a lot of good to be had by trying more of the menu.
author: Keith M.

description:
Sushi Not-So-Fantastic so far....

My coworkers and I have been 3 times and tried a wide sampling of rolls which were fair, but not a deal for the price.   I think there is a better value in the nigiri.  

There is something really weird with the rice.  It tastes... too plain.  I think they neglect to add enough vinegar or any at all.   If anyone in my family forgot the vinegar in the sushi rice, you might as well toss it all into the garbage and then kill yourself. 

The salad has an odd dressing that isn't very tasty and it is garnished with a sad thin slice of tomato and an even sadder dried up slice of carrot.  My coworker said, "Dang, I just want plain ol' thousand island.  Maybe that would make this edible.  You want it?"   The miso soup was pretty good.

They are also still working out the kinks with the service.  Just so's ya know, when you walk in you have to go upstairs and pay. They will give you a number to take down to your table where they will drop off your food.  There is free hot green tea that is self serve.  That is awesome except for the fact that the tea is upstairs while all the tables are DOWN stairs.  Carrying two steaming hot mugs of tea downstairs through a crowd of people waiting to order is pretty sketchy.  They should really move the tea downstairs.  

Sushi is ok.  Donburi bowls ok.  I would classify their portions as generous since you do get salad and rice with most of the lunch meals.  It's a nice addition to the area.

Hopefully this place will improve once they are producing their full menu.  As of 3/15/07 they are still not serving any noodle dishes or lunch bento boxes.  The only items you can order are sashimi, nigiri, sushi rolls, and donburi.

UPDATE 3/20/07:  Alex the head chef confirmed today that they do have alternative salad dressings, you just need to ask.  He also mentioned that once their kitchen is fully operational in a couple of weeks, they will be having promotions and deals.  I'll definitely check back again and see how the rest of their menu fares.
author: Courtney Y.

description: Went back here and ordered the spicy tuna roll and tempura roll with miso soup and salad. The spicy tuna roll was almost WARM. Like room temperature. Blech. The tempura roll was soggy. Blech. The miso soup was just OFF - no miso, no broth, and the seaweed was off so it tasted rancid (or like ass). Standards are slipping, dudes!
author: Mi M.

description:
I dont know what some of the high expectations are for? I mean if you work in the SOMA slash lower Market/FD area then this is probably the best sushi you can find in a 1.5 mile radius within a $10 - 15 budget. The only other place to get seriously above fantastic sushi is Ozumo but that takes some overtime at work  and drug dealer tactics to afford the bill after a couple of rounds of sashimi, rolls, bento boxes and sake.

Ask the ladies in front when you walk up whats the better lunch special - A, B or C and they'll honestly tell you which one based on what they got that's fresh. I mean A is always the Chicken teriyaki bento box (which in my opinion if you're gonna eat that go to fuckin Jack-in-the-Box on 1st and get your fill). B is usually a special roll with some sashimi and California roll included in. C is the last minute special that always changes every other day.

If you work in the SOMA, or across the street like me, then this place will be exactly what its name is, Sushi Fantastic. But if you expect great sushi, save yourself the dissapointment, save more of that lunch money and go to other gems in the city like....(I aint gonna tell you cuz then you'll potentially take my reservation the next time I might be there)
author: Nick V.

description:
My first review ever.  Unfortunately, its for Sushi Fantastic.  After being a sideline member for 2 yrs, I thought I should or needed to warn SF of this place.  Its bad, oh so bad.

I ordered the tempura udon:

Good - Its close to where I work and ummm, and, well, I think that's it.  No wait, they did have the fork, spoon and napkin all rolled up, ready to go so that's a plus.

Bad - Everything else.  One of the tempura had uncooked batter inside of it.  I tried to ignore it and fight through but there is only so much tempura batter a man can eat before giving up.

I realize there is only so much you can do with packaged udon.  But come on, you have a deep fryer, use it.  Cook that sucker all the way through.
author: Chad N.

description:
When I was in college, I dreamed of eating sushi or crepes every day. This dream may seem humble to you, but it was dashed for years because these things tend to be expensive and far from work.

Sushi Fantastic may not be worthy of Nobu's endorsement, but they serve affordable and healthy sushi right across the street from my office.  I especially like the ladies who run the place, they are super cute and funny and they barely give me the abuse I deserve for ordering the same thing every day.
author: Cassio P.

description:
I would give Sushi Fantastic five stars for convenience if I could- but that wouldn't really serve a broader audience.  However, for those of you who work in SOMA, you know what I'm talking about when I say there's a real scarcity of places to grab lunch.  Those folks on the other side of Market don't know how good they have it, what with Chinatown and Northbeach at their backdoor and the convenience of what I like to call the Kearny food fair.  

Sushi Fantastic is a relatively new establishment (opened in March).  For a long time they've had tempura listed on the menu, but they don't actually serve it yet (or maybe they do now? Please correct me if I'm wrong).  But that's okay because the sushi and the udon is decent and modestly priced, and, much better than the prepack stuff out there.  However, this is not "fantastic" sushi.  Or "fantastic" Japanese food.  But it's solid, and I wouldn't expect mind-blowing sushi fare at these prices.  

One of my favorite things about this place is the Sapporo on tap (surprise, surprise that I seek out the booze!).  The beer always seems to taste like it came out of a fresh keg- aromatic and effervescent with a nice flower on top.  Also, the beef udon is really a star dish here, with beef that is tender and flavorful.

Last but certainly not least, I would also give the staff five stars for their kind, welcoming spirit and good service.  I truly value an eatery that doesn't serve up portions of rude.
author: Chalk A.

description:
I'm not looking for authenticity, I'm only looking for the best quality relative to the price being charged. 

This place, was definately overpriced, and very skimpy non-japanese food. Every mediocre or bad review on here, pretty much covers my sentiments - including the under cooked batter on the tempura. I"m wondering if the rolls are any better - since I had a tuna bento lunch. I would be brave and try to come back again for something else, but I highly doubt that right now.

Well, if I'm going to compare apples to apples and oranges to oranges, I would really recommend you going to Teriyaki Express in the food court  on Spear and Mission, instead. Much better quality and porportions for about the same price or cheaper.
author: Mai T.

description:
This place sells premade sushi and bento boxes.  I'll say, it is perfectly suitable for lunch-time sushi.  Fast, good portions, reasonable prices.  I typically get the Sushi combo B which gives me 10 total pieces along with salad and soup...all for $10.95...and it's perfectly packaged to go.  Also, you get hot tea for free.  

With all that being said, I don't think I'd come here for dinner sushi.  When I go to get sushi for dinner, I want quality fish, made to order.  This is not one of those types of places.  

Enjoy it for your mid-day sushi hankering but for that alone.
author: Susan L.

description: Japanese fast food at the price of a quality lunch. Wilted vegetables, non-fresh fish, and lackluster flavors are inexcusable when so many better lunch options are nearby. I will not return.
author: Corry F.

description:
Overall 3.5 Stars
It's so hard to find an affordable sushi place around work.  My co-worker and I went to this place for lunch today.  Not the freshest sushi around, but for the price and location it's a good place to satisfy your sushi craving while in the area.

Location: 5 Stars
It's close to my work and close to Market.  The restaurant is modern, clean and nice.

Food: 3.5 Stars
They have a decent size menu from bento boxes, to sushi.  The sushi was okay.  Not the greatest, but when you're craving sushi at an affordable price this is a good place to go.  Many lunch box, and combo plate specials to choose from.  The speciality rolls seem better than the combos.  Unlimited hot tea is a treat.

Service: 4 Stars
It's a grab and find your seat type of place, but the check-out process was easy and the staff were SUPER Nice.  The food came out quick and the clean-up was fast enough to keep people in and out and a constant rate.
author: Manohak S.

description:
DO NOT GET SASHIMI HERE.  PLEASE AVOID IT LIKE THE BUBONIC PLAGUE.

The donburi is okay.  I got the unagi donburi the first time and it was decent.  Unagi to rice proportion was off, though - way too much rice for the amount of unagi you get.  This was about $8.

Got the chirashi bowl the next time and I felt the need to thoroughly soak each sashimi piece in my soy sauce-wasabi mix before eating.  The fish is not fresh and not tasty.  Even the rice lacked :[  The chirashi bowl was a waste of $11.

People seem to be generally nice, though.  They were attentive to getting a table ready for us.
author: L Y.

description:
Everyone here has made the same obvious Sushi "Fantastic" joke so I'll spare you.

this place : sushi :: walmart : fashion

That is, this place has sushi that will not kill you, is cheap, and is close to work.
author: Michael M.

description:
Ok. Nice ambiance when it's not jam packed (it gets packed for lunch around 12 = no seats) 

The california rolls are ok - the avocado can only be found with a microscope. 

This place is definitely NOT fantastic - it's more like completely mediocre.

The lady at the cash register gave me major attitude when I wanted to use my credit card (- 1 star). The food runners are quick and friendly.
author: Chili B.

description:
Pretty good, if you take it for what it is: a lunch spot for all us FiDi workers.

The service: I only go there once every couple of weeks, but the employees recognize me. Even the owner, Alex! The friendly service is  what keeps me coming back, even though Tokyo Express on Spear and Howard is closer and more convenient to me. Come to think of it though, I recognize a few of the employees as former Tokyo Express workers...

The food: The sushi is fresher than TE, but be careful of the spicy tuna and spicy hamachi rolls. They mean it when they say spicy! I agree with the other reviews about the miso soup. Mushrooms? Really? No thanks. The items on the cooked food menu are all pretty standard. Haven't tried most of it though, since I'm usually there for the fish.
author: Amy C.

description:
a sushi "restaurant" that closes at 5pm, nuff said.

i ordered a sushi lunch combination B, 8 piece california roll, 6 piece nigiri, with miso soup and salad.

the nigiri looked a little filmy and not super fresh, but it was hard to tell how fresh it actually was because the slices were almost deli-thin. the california roll was not super chintzy, but not abundant with filling either.

the sides, salad and miso soup, would have been totally acceptable if i weren't hung up on what i came for: the rolls.

i know a lot of people put the most weight in judging a sushi place on the freshness of the fish, but it's hard for me to weigh in on that because there was a fundamental flaw in all of the rolls i ordered: the rice.

sushi rice preparation is probably the most important consideration for a sushi restaurant as it's present in any unagi, ebi, toro (not offered here btw) or other nigiri or custom roll... and their rice was just bad in my opinion. sushi rice should be prepared that it tastes and feels fresh, the rice on their rolls was way too soft (old), not at all sticky, and tasted pretty much like it was pulled out of a rice cooker that was made for filling sides of rice bowls... you need rice vinegar, sugar, and salt, owners; not a huge expense on your pocketbook! if they improve the preparation of their sushi rice, i'd bump them up a few stars.

my experience was that the food was mostly bland. the fish wasn't particularly flavorful, and the california roll was nothing memorable, but the only thing i thought about while eating it was that the rice the cooks make is so bad it negates any good that might be offered by them.

2 stars given because of the location if you work at a nearby company and there aren't other sushi places in the area, and also because of the portion ($9.50 pre-tax sushi combo B) to food ratio; it's not that expensive.

tl;dr: inexpensive, but don't expect good sushi... the rice sucks
author: bob s.

description: HORRIBLE! Everything from the food to the customer service is sub sub par. I just took one bite of the tempura and it was disgusting. terriyaki chicken was also flooded in sugary sauce. I took one bite and I couldn't even swallow it, it was so bad. The only thing edible was the miso soup . Worst of all my horrible lunch, which I didn't eat, cost almost $10. not worth it at all. i want my money and time back.
author: Jessica N.

description:
I just went there for lunch yesterday, and was so stoked to find a sushi place near my work!

I didn't think this place was bad at all.

It's a great lunchtime place. It's fast. It's convenient, all in a hip little cafe setting. It's just as expensive as cold sushi from Safeway, but I think it's way better. I don't think this place is meant to be a gourmet sushi restaurant, so I'm not going to pretend that it is.

The menu was pretty decent-sized and I didn't know what to order. So, I just ordered the special: Volcano Roll + 1/2 Cali Roll with Soup and Salad for $9.50.

I sat down, and before I could even take my coat off, the waiter had brought me my soup and salad which I thought were fantastic. The salad tasted fresh to me, and the mayo-dressing was good. The soup was also very yummy. There's also all these sauces and spices to play with. Well, like 4, but still...

I'm a pretty fast eater, but before I could even finish my soup and salad, the waiter had brought my Volcano and Cali rolls. They were pretty good. They tasted like Volcano and Cali rolls. It was good, and it satisfied me.

And the staff is Thai, not Chinese. I heard them speaking Thai to one another.
author: Paweena P.

description:
As sushi places go, it's so-so. 

It's in a very convenient location if you work south of market. They have fast service for when you must have a taste of seaweed during a brief lunch break.

I was pleased enough with them after 9 visits, but the 10th visit was a bad one. While their lunch specials and bento boxes are good enough, stay away from the a la carte sushi menu. My spicy tuna roll was inedible.
author: Rue M.

description:
Should be called "Sushi OK". 

Not great, not terrible. Ok for a quick lunch. If you go, the rice bowls are your best bet.
author: Amanda B.

description:
Pretty good lunch option in the area! I like their bento boxes and the don options. The bento boxes (my personal favorite is salmon) include soup, salad, tempura and is very good value for money! I have also tried the garlic shrimp which is pretty good too. I ordered that once with rice and it was pretty good for lunch. 

I haven't ordered a lot of their items but I would say it is certainly worth giving a shot.
author: Rita R.

description:
i just got lunch take out from this sushi place and it was SOOOO GROSSSSS. they must save the janky meat for the to-go orders cuz you're not going to walk back from your office and ask them to re-make the order.  UGH.

before i would have given this place 3 stars cuz it was my go-to when i felt like japanese food (which is often since i get palate fatigue from the weekly salad, soup, sandwich routine).  I have had the sushi (ate in) and it was passable.  I also like the veggie udon, cuz it has a lot of veggies going on in it that I can justify the starchy noodle consumption.

but my order today just threw that out the door.  
my sashimi slices had VEINS in it.  I know fish HAVE veins but I HAVE NEVER see them poking out of my maguro. 

i feel so violated. i think i need to take a half day.
author: Jessica H.

description:
Am I a sushi gourmet ? I am not.

The ladies at the counter are nice.

The sushi is good, is it mind boggling good ? I don't know, who the fuck cares ? Is everything you eat mind boggling good ? It isn't. You won't admit it but you could probably eat cold ravioli out of a can in a pinch and be very happy.

It's fast and I like that, I am generally out in under 5 mins from the time I step foot in the door.

So they're nice, it's fast, the prices are reasonable and for that I like it.

You want more ? I'm sure you do and that is because you are a spoiled overindulged brat who has an opinion of yourself that is waaaaaay over inflated.

Relax, go have some sushi, and try not to take yourself so seriously, cause trust me, no one else does.
author: red c.

description:
A Monday - Friday office lunch favorite!  I've converted many Tokyo Express goers to this sushi joint.  Not only is it an elevator ride down for my lunch crew, the fish is fresh and you can actually SEE the fish unlike Tokyo Express.  

I highly recommend the 49er roll.  Only 6bucks which includes a california roll with pieces of tobiko and salmon on top.  The best part?  The lil slices of lemon on each piece that gives the roll an extra zing & zap in your mouth at lunchtime.

So why only 2.5 Stars?
-  If you've read my Okina Sushi review, you'll understand why.  I just can't give a faux-sushi place 5Stars.  Minus 1 Star.
-  No HOT food!  The previous owners broke the stove before they left because they couldn't make it.  Just kidding.  That's our theory.  Once they get this fixed, I'll bump up it up.  Minus 1 Star.
-  If you decide to eat there, they're number system (or lack of) is just WHACK!  Pay attention to your order. Minus 0.5 Star.
author: Yoko H.

description: I appreciate how they include the soup as well since a majority of the Japanese places don't want to give you soup when you do take out.  They also pack up the salad and anything else you need very neatly for those togo orders.  One of the better tasting sushi places around.  Other places that are more expensive are not as good.  $9.03 after tax for a chicken teriyaki with rice, kali roll or tempura, miso soup and salad.
author: Davey L.

description: This place is definitely NOT "fantastic".  The fish is stale and the portions are small.  At this point, I am just hoping that I do not get sick off what I ate.  Even the Miso soup was watered down.  I did not think anyone could mess up Miso soup, but apparently it is possible.  I will not return.
author: Dan O.

description: A solid 3-star lunch joint. Really, my favorite thing about this place are the two delightful cashiers that always bring a smile to my face. I work in the same building so I will come here again and again and always leave with a smile. I would never go here for dinner, but in SOMA, there are still very limited options these days, and this place is one of the better picks.
author: Brian J.

description:
My co-workers and I come here since it is right around the corner from our work. I always get the veggie udon soup. It comes with a small green salad too.  There are not a ton of veggie options here, but hey, it is Japanese. The tempura udon is also good.

The ladies at the register are always very nice.
author: Janet B.

description: I use this place often for lunch. It is good for a quick Bento box or sushi roll. The place is too crowded for me between 12-1 so either come before or after.
author: Brian S.

description:
No no no no no! Definitely NOT a place you want to go for Sushi. I am eating a take-out order that I got from there for lunch, and felt compelled to write a review mid-meal. 

I ordered a Rainbow Roll and a Double Salmon Roll - both favorites from nearby Tokyo express (which raised their prices because they got greedy). 

Rule # 1 of Sushi - the fish must be fresh. From the taste and look of it, this fish isn't fresh. In fact, I'm really hoping that I don't get sick, as I've read other reviewers say they have fallen ill after eating here.  (Strike 1)

Rule # 2 of Sushi - well made sticky rice. I wish I had read the reviews of this place before I went there. I totally agree with the one reviewer who had clumps of rice falling off his sushi. Now people, I've been eating sushi for many many years, and can expertly pick up any roll, dip it in the soy sauce / wasabi mixture, and get it in my mouth without having it disintegrate. So my chopstick skills are not to blame. There were literally clumps of rice that were almost separated from the rest that fell off. Unbelievable!
(Strike 2)

To top it off, the not-so-fresh fish and the clumpy rice cost me $20. I don't mind paying for quality, but as we've established, this was no Fantastic Sushi, so $20 for 2 rolls....no way! 
(Strike 3)

Safe to say, I'm never going back. In fact, I just tossed the remainder of the sushi.
author: Samir P.

description:
Fantastic? I think not. Tolerably adequate? Maybe.  Decent prices for downtown are more than balanced out by mediocre fish (think stringy tuna), blackening avocado, and overcooked and mushed rice.

My brother's udon looked good though...so maybe this isn't a great place for sushi, but alright for the other stuff.
author: Eugene F.

description:
Great lunch spot. Fast and cheap. Order upstairs and they deliver. Th combos could be considered small by some people, but I thought it was reasonable for the price. 

Peak lunch-time may have trouble finding a seat!
author: Joe L.

description:
This is not so much Sushi Fantastic as Sushi Mediocre. In a nutshell, while I avoid cold (like out of the refrigerator cold) sushi, neither should sushi be WARM. Yes, the avocado and California rolls I am currently consuming could veritably be deemed WARM. At least I'm not eating warm sashimi. 

Also, as I've noted previously, cucumber does not belong in California rolls. Perhaps they think the California roll is a better deal when you get some extra cucumber in it, but I think it's just a rude interruption to the creaminess of the avocado and crab (in this case, artificial crab rather than the real stuff).

And finally, I don't think I've ever actually seen rice falling off sushi, but I'm taking it as a bad sign from now on... putting whole sushi rolls in your mouth is not exactly glamorous as it is -- who needs the extra humiliation of little rice globs dropping off mid-plate-to-mouth trajectory?
author: J C.

description:
So far, when I'm looking for a sushi indulgence during my work-lunch-hour, I make the trek out to this fine establishment. That alone, says, "this place is decent enough for this guy to travel what he describes as a 'trek' for some sushi."

Yes, the place is good. Not AMAZING...but good. I always leave satisfied. The times I've come, I've only gotten rolls, which haven't disappointed. I am interested in getting their bento boxes. They seem like a lot of food for not a lot of money. The last I saw, their special of the day included: rice, teriyaki chicken, miso soup, salad and 4 CA rolls...all for $8. Not bad.

Conclusion, I'll come here to fill that craving on occasion....but I won't come here "regularly."
author: Jon C.

description:
There are not a lot of sushi places in this part of SOMA. It's the closest sushi place to my work, so I was ecstatic when it opened. The prices are pretty reasonable ($3.50 for 8 piece CA roll, $4 for 6 piece Rock & Roll, bento boxes are between $7-10). It's pretty similar to Tokyo Express near the Rincon Center (which is the next closest place for cheap sushi). Their rolls are kind of sloppy, but it's fresh, and it's a pretty good size. I always get the Rock & roll, and you can actually taste all of the ingredients in there. 

It's not too crowded at lunch. I've been lucky and only had to wait about 5 minutes for my food. The staff is pretty friendly, which is a plus, especially when it gets busy. They also have hot tea there while you wait. They also deliver, but I'm not sure if there's a charge for it.
author: Ring K.

description:
It's close to work, pretty fast, and lots of food.  I have yet to try the sushi - but the teriyaki chicken bento box, with tempura, rice and salad was great.  For a quick, hot meal - the donburi chicken bowl was perfect.  I don't think I'll ever be totally cool with paying $10 for lunch, however, its the norm in the financial district, so I'll just suck it up when I'm too lazy to bring lunch...couple things, the donburi bowls come with soup and salad, which they pre-pack for efficiency....resutling in warm salad and cold soup. 

Ill definitely go there again, and eventually try the sushi!
author: Fräulein J.

description: Sad that this is the only sushi restaurant around this area because the food is not so tasty and the customer service is awful. I'm sure not coming back to this place.
author: Cita M.

description:
Lots of reasonably good food for a fair price. Quick, friendly service. Decently fresh fish. I've never had warm fish here, by the way.

I've been to Sushi Fantastic at least a dozen times (mainly because it's a block away form where I work) and never had a bad bite. It's not off the charts great but definitely worth a try.

Back last spring when construction was going on down the street, the construction workers used to have their lunch here. Seeing construction workers eating sushi - definitely one of those great only in San Francisco moments.
author: David G.

description: Hmmmm, I'm surprised by the poor reviews. This place is close to work and I wish I had found it sooner. Rolls are fresh and good! They also have spicy sauce on the table which is awesome as I always like some extra KICK! Good, cheap, casual lunch place!
author: Kadie B.

description:
It definitely depends on what you order. I suggest the sushi combos, but really did not like the tempura. It tasted old and bland to me. 

Positives: 
-Some of the best prices for the amount of food you get. 
-Service is quick, waiters are attentive and friendly. 
-Personally really like their sushi lunch combos. Comes with miso soup, salad, and more than enough sushi to be full. Never had a bad experience with it so far, and whereas it may not be as amazing as more expensive places, it hasn't been terrible. 

Negatives: 
-If you have trouble with loud, crowded places, this might not be the one for you, as the lunch rush can be intense and a few times friends and I have had to share tables with another party. 
-Really did not like their tempura. It tasted bland and not too fresh.
author: Sally O.

description:
As my former boss used to say:  "Good, fast and cheap.  Pick two."  This never seemed more true than when I sought out good, inexpensive sushi in the FiDi.
I ordered sushi box "B" for lunch, and it was blech.  The Cali roll was pretty good, but all the nigiri was pretty icky and had that less-then-fresh flavor.  The accompanying salad was pretty sad, and the miso soup was just like the instant stuff from a packet.  You can't expect much from a $9 sushi bento box, but I think they could have done a little bit better.  Maybe they could just leave out the soup and salad and use slightly better fish.   
It's in a convenient location for us in the SoMa/Fidi no-man's-land, and it's cheap, thus the two stars.
author: Michelle A.

description: Solid lunch spot. Quick service. Decent selection. Nothing mind-blowing,  but a good spot for takeout or a quick sushi lunch in the area.
author: Amy H.

description: Another place close enough for me to hit for lunch.. it's OK, the bento boxes seem to be around $11. I don't find the fish (sashimi) to be to terribly wonderful but I've had worse and I have had some that is better as well it's "just OK". This is decent middle ground when I'm craving sushi. The bento box does come with salad, soup and steamed rice which I greatly enjoy :-) I've only ever had take out so I don't know how table service is but everyone is very friendly and my food comes up pretty fast.
author: Abby S.

description:
BEWARE! 4 people in my office have been made sick by this place! Take one whiff at the top of the stairs and you should listen to your better judgment when your mind tells you it stinks! And what the hell are they doing advertising tempura???? they don't have it, haven't ever had it, and when asked, say " we get fryer next week".

Although a limited selection, Sushi next door at Spazio is MUCH better.
author: Luke P.

description:
probably ordered sushi combo b from here a few dozen times. it's not bad.

i stopped going recently when the unagi went missing from sushi b.
author: Andy P.

description: Pretty decent place to get my sushi/japanese fix for lunch. The sushi is pretty good & the udon or soba noodle soups are pretty flavorful. I also LOVE how quick they're service is. This place can get really crowded w/ people waiting for their orders, but dont worry you will be out of there w/in 5 minutes!!!
author: Krystel M.

description:
you won't find nobu here...

nobu (the resident yelp sushi jedi) will probably never approve sushi fantastic, but i'm not nobu.......and for slightly more than what you would pay for trader joe's sushi, you can get yourself a decent california roll or spicy tuna that's better than whole food's sushi for lunch at this new location in soma. hence my days of lugging a week worth of trader joe's sushi and having wild dogs barking at me like i'm a giant sashimi on my way to the mission bart station is officially over. amen and hallelujah! solid three stars!
author: frisco j.

description: Maintains its 3-star status in my book.  Very fast to-go service.  I ordered 2 chicken teriyaki bentos for my coworkers.  Very moderately priced for the amount of food you get (comes with soup and salad). For myself I ordered a spicy tuna roll and a spicy salmon roll.  The salmon roll was not spicy enough.  Tuna roll was too spicy.  Too much sriracha I think?  Overall still tasty.  Rice was a little too sticky but that's what happens when they have to produce large quantities.  Quality of rice suffers a bit.  I like that they give you a litle sauce container with the wasabi and pickled ginger inside.  Makes for easy mixing when you add the soy sauce.  Except, I wish the pickld ginger was packed separately.  Some of the pieces had too much waasabi on it and made for a very unpleasant, unexpected  burn.
author: Jade K.

description:
hmmm, bold use of adjectives, i thought! but sushi fantastic IS fairly fantastic! the sushi is fresh and yummy and the service is friendly, but the fantastickest part about it is the location. we have LITTLE TO NO OPTIONS in our little corner of SOMA for lunchtime sushi; and not only is this an option, it is a good one! 

the avocado rolls are fabulous
the seaweed salad is phenomenal
the prices are magnificent
the location is perfection
 
fantastic idea.
author: tina s.

description:
if you want udon, go to tokyo express, if you want bento/teriyaki/grill go to imakura on beale st... but if you want sushi go here. 

oh, if you want to pay hellza money go to ozumo.

p.s. yelp has the wrong address. this place is on howard, not fremont.
author: Greg D.

description: Not really fresh sometimes fast but portions are big so for hungry people its a great place to go but not so much for good quality and not very authentic.
author: Joiera C.

description: I come here about once a week. The service is fast and responsive for such a high volume lunchtime destination. The food is good, but Japanese cuisine is not at the top of my list, so I can't rate that too much. The Don bowls are pretty good, as well as the boxes. The sushi seems hit or miss depending on the guy making it.
author: Mike P.

description: You have to lower your expectations when looking for Japanese food on your lunch break in this part of the South Beach district.  Sushi Fantastic is far from it's namesake, but it does have a decent California roll.  I was disappointed in the salmon don.  It's 3 slivers of grilled salmon that has barely any flavor on top of flavorless veggies and then topped with sparse amounts of I believe is Teriyaki sauce.  None of the fried items are available at the moment.  Overall, its good variety that is needed around this area.
author: Jason A.

description: we had a private party last night, it was very good. very amazing just like it's name FANTASTIC...I would like to thank my boss to bring us there. we all had a very good time and we all loved the foods..i would like to go again, again and again for my dinner.! thanks Alex for making us the good and fresh foods.
author: Sa Y.

description:
Not so fantastic Sushi.  An insult to call it Japanese.  

After walking past this place for several weeks now I decided to give it a go yesterday and well let's just say that I won't be going back.  First, you have to stand in a very hot, and lacking fan or A/C room.  Second, the iced tea that I purchased for what I would consider a ridiculously inflated price for a snapple was... get this- tepid at best.  Third my spicy california roll came with rice granules falling pathetically all over the plate making it impossible to eat without a spoon.  Hmmm sushi with a spoon?!  Lastly, my Zaru Soba (buckwheat noodles) was overcooked and the "tsuyu" or dipping sauce was so salty and no where near what it should have tasted like.  This is what happens when you get people who have no clue about what good Japanese food should taste like!  Folks... other than the great location for all of us who live in SOMA, this food is definitely not a "bang for your buck" and leaves one unsatisfied.  In closing I have to mention how upset I was to find the "La Choy" soy sauce or whatever that cheap quality garbage was filled in the "Kikkoman" Lite soy sauce bottles.  Definitely not Kikkoman.
author: Alicia W.

description:
do not ever get their donburi...i got the katsu donburi and all it was was katsu with a few pieces of steamed veggies over rice...no sauce, no egg...way too dry

their bento boxes are ok though...it fulfills my teriyaki chicken / rice cravings when i'm at work
author: Alice K.

description: Hit or Miss.  I've been here 10 times and only gotten sick once.  I do go back although I only order items that don't include fish.
author: Jeremy P.

description: Been here twice and twice it's the same: Big rolls with  A LOT of rice and VERY LITTLE meat and no flavor. If you are in a pinch and need to satisfy hunger on a low budget this place works. If you have time to walk to Toyko Express go to Tokyo.
author: Jennifer And Uri W.

description:
After reading these reviews I had to sign up and help defend this great little lunch place. 

First, it's basically homemade "to order" fast food. You walk up to a counter to order. There are over 50 items on the menu not including all the sushi options, and also including terriyaki snapper, udon/s, soba, and more. A full lunch is about $11. They serve you at comforable tables or bar tables, they give you free hot tea, and keep a very clean and friendly environment. Sushi Fantastic serves great lunches from an open kitchen. It's very clean. 

What Sushi Fantastic did most of you go to? Did you imagine you were at Nobu? Reality check: it's lunch time in the city and you have $10-$20/ 30-60 minutes and you want fresh Japanese. Seriously, the last time I read such whiney reviews was when some lady couldn't wait to leave an ethnic restaurant to get a triple dab dipped frappucino at Starbucks.
author: M M.

description:
Two stars notwithstanding, I will still come back to this place. I mean, it's in my building, so it's quick and the price is on par with other restaurants around me. But in future I will just be careful...very careful...about what I order.

I usually come here when I have a sushi craving, and while the Sushi A combo promises value and speed, it really is not worth it. Today the California roll was tasty and seemed to be reasonably fresh, but the nigiri pieces it came with smelled bad, and had discolorations on the fish where they had been nestled snugly against each other for who knows how long. I threw them away. The soup is good and hot, but the salad is worthless. So the value of the combo is sort of lost when you throw half of it in the garbage.

I would come back here for just the California roll, or for something cooked. But no more sushi combos for me, thank you very much.
author: Marie C.

description: Yeah, not sure "fantastic" is the best descriptor for this place. The selection was good, the prices reasonable, but was not too happy when my sushi fell apart, and some random avocado that was not a part of the sushi description appeared. Inspect your eats before you chow down.
author: Jason B.

description: I wouldn't say this place is fantastic, but it's a decent Japanese place considering the other alternatives in the area.  I'd prefer Sushi Fantastic's actual rolls and sushi to their bento boxes.  I've had their chicken teriyaki bento and the meat was dry and a few sliced carrots were considered the veggies.  Nothing to rave about.  The dragon roll is really good and the California rolls are decent.  It's definitely good, but not fantastic.
author: Claire H.

description: When usual cheapo lunch spot "Dirty Sushi" closed (ok it wasn't called dirty sushi, I just called it that 'cause it's in the SOMA and I call everything in SOMA dirty) I thought half-way decent sushi was gone forever. Then Sushi Fantastic opened and it's much better. Sashimi lunch w/ miso and salad - money! And I don't have to battle the ferry plaza crowd to get my lunch on. 3 stars cause I can't call food served to me in a little plastic tray anything but 3 stars worthy - sorry kids it just ain't gonna happen.
author: Lauren D.

description: Great place that is fast.  I have only had the sushi which is pretty good.  It's like a sushi place that I remember seeing in the Japan subway.
author: Ginny M.

description: It's the only decent take-out Japanese place close to my work. *Sigh* I haven't gotten disgusted or sick from the food yet, so I will continue to give them business when I simply can't wait until after work to get Japanese food. If my dad saw me eating their food, he might faint though. A real Japanese dad won't let his little girl eat food from here.
author: Su K.

description: So it's not authentic Japanese. And the ambience is kinda shabby. And warm. But you know what? It's still healthy food. And inexpensive. And made fresh for you, not sitting in bento boxes for hours already. I had much worse for $10, really.
author: Roland A.

description: I am sure they have other good stuff on the menu. I just can't help not ordering udon every time I pop in this restaurant. Occasionally, I will add an order of sashimi, of coz' together with my udon to go. They are really busy during lunch time, if you are thinking of getting take out, you should call to put in your order.
author: Ervinna L.

description:
I work right by Sushi Fantastic, but didn't discover that fact until I was Yelp-ing the other day at work. (SHH!)

Sushi is my favorite food, and during lunch, I don't experience ambiance or service much. I grab my food to-go and get back to work to make those dolla dolla bills, ya'll.

So I am basing my review purely on takeout standards (I would give the place 5 stars in that category)

Super fresh fish.
Great prices.
Quickly made.
Super friendly staff.
Yummy.
I love it -- I'm going back every workday.
author: Jackie C.

description: gross. i went against my better judgement and just tried to cover the fishy taste of my rolls with as much soy sauce as i could get my hands on (since i did pay $13 after all). couldn't finish the strangely just above room temperature edamame, even after i picked out the brown shrively ones. left me feeling generally icky and regretting that decision.
author: Anne C.

description: I can only judge the sushi/sashimi, I have not tried the bento or udon. If you like your sashimi luke warm and room temp then please by all means, enjoy. The tuna tastes like its been sitting in the sun for a couple hours. I gave them several tries due to the fact it is one block from my office, but my stomach could not allow me to return after I saw them gutting a fish behind the ordering counter. That coupled with my previous warm fish experience was enough to make me want to throw up everytime I walk passed on my way to Soup co.
author: Lizzie S.

description: While the sushi here leaves much to be desired, I really like the udon. The udon here is nothing special, but it is consistently decent, and at a good price point for Fidi lunch time fare. When I'm too lazy to walk to Chinatown for a bowl of pho, a bowl of udon will partially satisfy my noodle soup craving.
author: Erin Y.

description: considering this is basically a FiDi lunchtime 'fast food' joint, it delivers quite nicely.  i got a couple of rolls and miso soup.  it was delivered to my table within 5 minutes despite the line out the door.  not the best sushi ever, but def not the worst.  i am looking forward to trying an array of their japanese offerings, including the udon on cold days.  to avoid standing in the ling line, suggest going in at 1pm, it is cleared out by then.
author: e w.

description: One star for being open after 3pm on a weekday in these parts. Lost 4 stars because as I stood at the cashier for 5 minutes, nobody behind the counter even acknowledged me. The cook looked at me, but didn't say anything to anyone, the cashier was nowhere to be seen and the bus-person looked at me but totally ignored me while they ate their own food but clearly saw me. Come on...if you are open, you need to provide service. This place isn't even all that great the other times I have been there either. No wonder all the spots around this place have closed down...I think it might be next.
author: Michelle M.

description: Typical Japanese fast food place.  Sushi is not great, but eatible. The best on the menu is the Chicken Katsu with Tempura Bento box.   Happy hour is suppositely pretty cheap, but they close so early I doubt anyone is able to take advantage of it.
author: grace C.
